zooming (actions)

The programmer can indicate at which level of detail a description of an action should appear by adding an integer immediately after the opening ‘//$’ of an annotation. Higher numbers indicate a finer level of detail; the zoom level is 0 by default, corresponding to the coarsest level of detail. This makes different zoom levels possible in visualizing the HTML output. [implemented zoom levels 0-1]

annotation

...
//$0 action 1
code
//$1 action 1.1
code
//$1 action 1.2
code
//$0 action 2
...

0 is optional, corresponds to the main actions.

representation in the diagram

Note: Try mouse over. This is a website visualization. In Flowgen, interactive zooming could be performed on mouse click. [The present zooming visualization is not interactive: all different zoom levels are displayed in the corresponding HTML file]

examples

int class::activity_method(){

int a;      

//$ action 1
int b=1;
int c=2;
//$1 action 1.1
std::cout << "do"<< b << endl;
//$1 action 1.2
std::cout << "do"<< c << endl;

//$0 action 2
std::cin >> a;

return 0;
}


Note: Try mouse over. This is a website visualization. In Flowgen, interactive zooming could be performed on mouse click. [The present zooming visualization is not interactive: all different zoom levels are displayed in the corresponding HTML file]

operational implementation of interactive zooming visualization

[not implemented]
A full diagram will contain in general several zoomable sections. For each of these sections, a certain zoom level choice gets assigned a certain code. Hence, a particular instance of a full diagram, as selected by the user, will contain a unique combination of these codes. Hyperlinks will connect among different instances (code combinations) of the same full diagram. Either:
1) The GUI browser sends a message to the diagram constructor to tell the latter what diagram exactly we want to see. REAL-TIME GENERATION (can save memory / space / time)
2) All possible diagrams are built beforehand. OFF-LINE GENERATION.
